ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Straightforward: A solid (I think) introduction to elementary Italian grammar. I would recommend this class to another student.

This class is MUCH easier than L1. It goes at a much slower speed (no more weekly tests) so that the information is actually digestible. The course also focuses a lot more on culture than L1, with several movies, an opera, readings from the Decameron, and even a trip to the art gallery. While I don't feel that my speaking has improved very much, I have a deeper appreciation for Italian culture from this class. Rachael is a really nice person, but if you really want to master the language, I'd take it with a native speaker. I guess this is true for all language classes, but I just feel like I lost out by not having a native speaker this semester. However, that said she is probably the easiest of the L2 professors and is a lenient grader. The class really isn't that much effort overall-- it almost feels like cheating that it's 1.5 credits.
A very good class for intermediate speakers. Pretty hard but you just have to put in the work. I would recommend this class to another student because it is engaing and helpful.
